awd_titl_txt: Postdoctoral Fellowship: PRFB: Investigating the biosynthesis and evolution of mesembrine alkaloids in Sceletium
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Plant Genome Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2024. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Dr. Colin Y. Kim is “Investigating the Biosynthesis and Evolution of Mesembrine Alkaloids in Sceletium”. The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Ryan S. Nett.

Plants synthesize various biochemicals to help them develop, adapt and survive various stresses experienced in their growth environment. Often, these molecules are unique to a group of species.  The rich molecular diversity present in plants provides a wide variety of valuable chemicals for food, nutrition, biofuels, and pharmaceuticals. Despite more than 400,000 plant species generating over 200,000 natural products, there is still limited understanding of the intricate biosynthetic pathways responsible for their production and the context for their emergence in a group of plant species. In particular, the complex structures of nitrogen-containing alkaloids produced by plants have not been extensively explored. This project aims to address this challenge by investigating how Sceletium plants build complex alkaloid chemical structures. This information is needed to discover plant biocatalysts and genomic signatures that can be harnessed to improve the production of valuable alkaloids for biomanufacturing and bioeconomy. The Fellow will receive training in genomics, chemical biosynthesis, and bioinformatics from this project. To facilitate scientific communication and promote community participation, the fellow will engage students from the Boston Area schools on science outreach and provide opportunities for undergraduates from the host institution on experiential learning on scientific research. The Fellow will also mentor students performing scientific research and disseminate plant metabolism research through organizing the 2025 Gordon Research Seminar for Plant Metabolic Engineering and a natural product biosynthesis mini-symposium in the Boston-area focus group.

The fellowship will focus on the biosynthesis of mesembrine alkaloids, using it as a model to investigate key catalytic steps in alkaloid scaffold formation and their metabolic evolution in Sceletium tortuosum. The specific objectives include 1) probing the metabolic landscape and transcriptome of Sceletium to elucidate the biosynthetic pathway of mesembrine alkaloids and 2) examining the Sceletium genome to identify genomic signatures for convergent evolution of mesembrine alkaloid biosynthesis. The Fellow will leverage metabolomics, transcriptomics, genomics, structural biology, and bioinformatics approaches to gain a comprehensive understanding of mesembrine biosynthesis. The omics datasets generated from this project will be accessible to the public through various community resource-sharing websites including the raw nucleotide sequencing reads on NCBI Sequence Read Archive and gene annotation data on NCBI BioStudies repositories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plants make up more than 80 percent of the Earth’s biomass and are key contributors to the chemical diversity of natural products harnessed for the bioeconomy. In fact, more than 75 percent of nitrogen-containing alkaloids are produced by plants. Yet, the biosynthesis of most plant alkaloids with valuable bioactivities remains underexplored. This study focused on the biosynthesis of mesembrine-type alkaloids, which are procognitive and antidepressant alkaloids with a unique chemical scaffold, produced by Sceletium tortuosum (Kanna). Mesembrenone, one of the main bioactive mesembrine-type alkaloids in Kanna, acts as a phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitor and contributes to the cognitive-enhancing and anti-inflammatory effects. While various total chemical synthetic routes have been reported for mesembrine-type alkaloids due to their distinctive chemical structure, relatively little is known about how the Kanna plant naturally produces them. During my brief funding period (August 1, 2024 - January 14, 2025), I obtained two high-quality transcriptomes of Kanna at mature and seedling developmental stages, along with diverse tissue-specific metabolomics data, and I am presently in the process of assembling a chromosomal-level genome of Kanna. Leveraging a multi-omics-guided approach, I elucidated the complete biosynthetic pathway of mesembrenone, identifying 10 genes, including an oxidase that catalyzes C-C bond formation and subsequently initiates a chemical cascade leading to the characteristic mesembrine-scaffold. Deciphering the biosynthesis of mesembrenone deepens our fundamental understanding of how neuroactive alkaloid scaffolds are generated and provides insights to better engineer and produce plant-derived medicines. 

I am deeply grateful for the support of the NSF PRFB funding, which has enabled me to pursue my research while also advancing my mission to enhance societal awareness of the importance of plant metabolism in our daily lives. During the funding period, I had the opportunity to serve as an outreach mentor at Boston Green Academy, a local public high school. In this role, I taught students about various plant-derived molecules that are often overlooked, and I aimed to spark their interest in pursuing science-related careers. Additionally, I demonstrated a common experimental technique from my research project, which involves using the model plant Nicotiana benthamiana to produce non-native biomolecules like glowing proteins on its leaves or pigment molecules found in beets. These hands-on experiences for the high school students were intended to inspire them to appreciate the ability for plants to make molecules that are valuable in human lives, but also to consider careers in science. Towards the end of the outreach program, I also had the chance to share my own career trajectory and encourage the students to maintain an open mindset about scientific careers.

Beyond the high school outreach, I have organized the 2025 Gordon Research Seminar in Plant Metabolic Engineering, scheduled to take place on June 14-15, 2025 in Barcelona, Spain. This event will feature a keynote speaker, as well as career panelists from industry, publishing, government, and academia, providing early-career scientists with valuable insights and opportunities to share their research. Additionally, in collaboration with Dr. Jing-Ke Weng's laboratory at Northeastern University and my sponsor's laboratory, we have organized "The 1st Symposium on Plant Biochemistry in Greater Boston," which took place on August 30, 2024. I am currently working to help plan the next iteration of this symposium, scheduled for May 2025. The funding from this award has enabled me to engage in various mentorship and teaching opportunities, and I am committed to continuing my efforts to broaden societal appreciation for plant metabolism research.

Lastly, this funding opportunity has allowed me to share my research progress at the "Natural Product Discovery and Development in the Genomic Era" conference, held from January 5-9, 2025. I intend to disseminate the data and associated findings from this project through scientific publication.
